blogs.title: Blameless Things
blogs.description: My name is Haden Plouffe, and I am/do a lot of things. For my do’s, I am a pianist, composer, aspiring musicologist, and perpetual player of any game by FromSoftware. As for who I am, I am an autistic trans lesbian in my mid twenties, lover of my wife and cats, and my life thus far has been a gradual descent into the stranger realms of art. I’ll be reflecting on art, artists, the sort of work I love, and the sort of work I want to make as I move through a world that is increasingly hostile to people like me.

blogs.title: Ether Diver
blogs.description: Musical journeys through inner space
blogs.myDescription: Ether Diver's blog includes the very cool "Other People's Music" series, which reviews and promotes independent music from around the web.

blogs.title: Kristoffer Lislegaard
blogs.description: Kristoffer Lislegaard is a Norwegian experimental ambient musician and producer based in Oslo. Since 2010, he has created, performed and released music as a solo artist as well as in various duo and ensemble formats, combining genres such as ambient, noise, post-rock, club music and more. He has also composed and sound designed contemporary dance, theatre, film, art installations, poetry and performance art.

blogs.title: Meljoann
blogs.myDescription: Meljoann is a multidisciplinary artist from Ireland. They describe their music as “hyperjack”—i.e., a hyperpop-flavored take on 90s new jack swing—and as “mutant R&B.” She is an active member of the independent music community on the Fediverse, and the Spirit of Gravity musical collective.

blogs.title: Nathan Ho
blogs.description: I started this as an outlet to write about music technology, where my main interests concern tools for creating experimental and left-field electronic music (particularly computer music, glitch, noise, and IDM). With my writing, I’m interested in bridging the worlds of music tech journalism with in-depth academic papers to create resources for technically proficient musicians.

blogs.title: a closer listen
blogs.description: Since 2012, A Closer Listen has claimed a specialized niche in the music industry: instrumental album reviews!  By concentrating on this above all else, we’ve built a healthy fanbase and a strong reputation. If music is recorded and nobody listens, does it still make a sound?

blogs.title: Noise Not Music
blogs.description: Welcome to Noise Not Music. Here you’ll find reviews of recent albums, various features and lists, and occasional mixes. I do not agree with the statement I’ve chosen as the title for this site (which has been around much longer than me). Everything I write about here—a great deal of which is called “noise”—is music.

blogs.title: Outside Noise
blogs.description: We scour the internet for its best kept sonic secrets and deliver them to you daily. Reviews of new underground albums hit our social outlets and blog every day. We also put in our two cents on select major releases that we consider relevant to the world of DIY music.

blogs.title: it's her factory
blogs.description: Robin James is a writer, editor, and former associate professor of philosophy at UNC Charlotte. […] She’s an expert in feminism/gender/race and popular music, pop music and politics, sound studies, electronic dance music studies, and contemporary continental philosophy (especially critical theories of neoliberalism and biopolitics).

blogs.title: Sounding Out!
blogs.description: Sounding Out! is a bi-weekly online publication, a networked academic archive, and a dynamic group platform bringing together sound studies scholars, sound artists and professionals, and readers interested in the cultural politics of sound and listening.  Every Monday, our writers offer well-researched, well-written, and accessible interventions in sound studies, directing the field’s energy toward the social, cultural, and political aspects of sound and listening, particularly their differential construction of and material impacts on variously positioned bodies.

blogs.title: Other Networks
blogs.description: “Other Networks” is a cluster of projects headed up by Dr. Lori Emerson and Dr. libi striegl that document and experiment with networks outside of what’s now called “the internet.” We are invested in digging up alternative and forgotten networks so that we can reimagine the future of the internet as the future of networks.

blogs.title: Paloma Kop
blogs.description: I am an experimental multimedia artist and creative technologist currently based in New Haven, CT. My practice incorporates electronic media, from analog video and synthesizers to digital systems and code, as well as various physical materials and processes. I am especially interested in feedback loops, recursion, self-organizing and emergent structures, patterns in nature, psychedelia, and embodied sensory experience.

blogs.title: anhvn
blogs.description: hi there! i’m anh, a designer and artist. this website is where i do silly web experiments and put all my personal content. it’s often experimental and messy so please pardon the dust!!

blogs.title: ArtLung : Joe Crawford
blogs.description: Hi. I’m Joe. This is my personal website. It’s got lots of stuff! I’ve written code for a living for a while. ArtLung.com itself runs on WordPress and it looks and works the way it does because I programmed the theme and underlying code.

blogs.title: Benjamin Parry
blogs.description: My name is Benjamin Parry. I live is Lewes, East Sussex, UK. I’m a design researcher, sushi maker novice, sushi eater expert, Japanophile, mountain bike rider, cold water swimmer, bread baker.

blogs.title: benji
blogs.description: I'm a software developer from Guayaquil, Ecuador now living in Minneapolis, MN with my wife, two kids, and a cat.

blogs.title: BinaryDigit ˗ˏˋ★ˊˎ˗
blogs.description: Hi, I’m B. I love the small web, sketching art, live streaming, retro tech, travel, and photography. Welcome to my digital brain dump and city center. Say hi on Mastodon, Bluesky or email. I live with my partner and two husky lab twins dogs in Michigan.

blogs.title: Fractal Kitty
blogs.myDescription: Someone I know from the IndieWeb who makes math art, haikus, and maker projects, among many other things.

blogs.title: gRegor Love
blogs.description: music · faith · computer geekery · friends · liberty: These six words are probably the most succinct bio I could write.

blogs.title: James' Coffee Blog
blogs.description: Hello! Привіт! I'm James (/d͡ʒeɪmz/) (also capjamesg). My pronouns are he/him/his. I live in Scotland. This is my blog. I hope this website can bring a little bit of joy into your day.

blogs.title: Jo's Blog
blogs.description: Hello, my name is Johanna, but online I am called Jo, and this is my website!! I've been putting out internet sites from this address since March 2022, so I haven't been "self"-hosting† for long.

blogs.title: Maggie Appleton
blogs.description: On the side I create illustrated essays and visual explanations about programming and culture. I'm an advocate of digital gardening , end-user programming , and expanding our use of embodied cognition and conceptual metaphors in digital interfaces.

blogs.title: Nick Simson
blogs.myDescription: Nick is someone I know from the IndieWeb Homebrew Website Club. I appreciate his writing about typography, especially his 26 Days of Type series.

blogs.title: njms
blogs.description: I'm an environmental computer scientist. I write about nature, epistemology, spirituality, and how they pertain to computer things. I've been maintaining this website for as long as I can remember. Here, you can find my art, writing and software.

blogs.title: Olu Online
blogs.description: I’m Olu Niyi-Awosusi. I live in London. My pronouns are they/them. I'm currently a developer in local government with a frontend focus.
blogs.myDescription: I especially appreciate Olu's notes page — they use it for "thinking out loud, sketching things out, getting feedback and learning in public/working with the garage door up/showing my work." The notes link to each other, and I like the design.

blogs.title: Ross A. Baker
blogs.description: Yeah, well, I’m going to go build my own site.     With Emacs! And Nix! In fact, forget the site. This is my personal brand, my love letter to the Indieweb, my finely manicured digital garden, my faffing about as I rediscover the joy of computing. Perpetually under construction.

blogs.title: Tracy Durnell's Mind Garden
blogs.description: I’m a sci-fi writer, graphic designer and urbanist in the Seattle suburbs. Reading and blogging are my favorite pasttimes and I’m an advocate of the indie web. I’m curious about everything from technology to history to ecology. I use this website to: track what I read and watch, write commentary on things that interest me, and save reference information.

blogs.title: [citation needed]
blogs.description: Keep up with the happenings in the tech world without all the boosterism. Cryptocurrency critic, technology researcher, and software engineer Molly White publishes Citation Needed, a newsletter that features regular explainers of developments in the cryptocurrency industry, with summaries of the latest disasters featured on her well-known project Web3 is Going Just Great. The newsletter also features deep dives into important events in the technology industry, with added critical context that is too often missing.

blogs.title: maia arson crimew
blogs.description: hey! im maia arson crimew (it/she), welcome to my website! this site is primarily home to my blog, containing my investigative journalism, work on hacktivism and technical articles on some of my own hacks. i also write a column called cyber_punk for the swiss online magazine das lamm (in german). outside my journalistic and activist work i try to make music, am a live dj and do various other creative things.

blogs.title: Where's Your Ed At
blogs.myDescription: Ed Zitron writes critically about the rot and growth-at-all-costs mentality in the tech industry, with a frequent focus on the deep-seated problems of “generative AI” corporations.
